title: Explore Argenteuil Castle and its royal connections
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Built in 1930 by businessman William Tuck on an estate founded a century earlier, it was for many years a “place of exile” for King Leopold III and his second wife Lilian Baels. Following a multi-million euro renovation, it is now owned by the Périer-D'Ieteren family holding company: Argenteuil Castle is where the Queen Elisabeth Music Chapel will soon take up residence. Discover the remarkable and eventful history of the building!
content: The Argenteuil estate is located in Waterloo, south of Brussels, on the edge of the Sonian Forest. It comprises 136 hectares of woodland and meadows, several ponds and buildings. And a large deer herd.
From next year onwards, music will fill the rooms of Argenteuil Castle, as the

will be able to use it. Established in 1939, the Queen Elisabeth Music Chapel, named after art loving Elisabeth of Bavaria, Queen of Belgians and King Albert I’s consort, provides high-level training to exceptional young musical talents.
After all, Argenteuil is an estate with a special pedigree, closely linked to the history of Belgium and its royal family.

It was banker Ferdinand de Meeûs, first governor of the Société Générale de Belgique after Belgian independence, who founded the estate between 1833 and 1836.  It was King William I, monarch of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands, who in 1822 established the Generale Maatschappij to stimulate growth and investment in the south of his new kingdom, the regions that are today Belgium.  The Generale Maatschappij became the Société Générale de Belgique after Belgian independence.  Till 1850 it also served as Belgium’s central bank.  De Meeûs built the first castle in Argenteuil in 1847, but that burned down shortly afterwards. A second castle followed in 1858, designed by architect Jean-Pierre Cluysenaar, who also designed the famous Saint Hubert’s Galleries in the Brussels downtown.
That castle still exists today. It first provided a home to Carmelite nuns, later became the Scandinavian School Queen Astrid, and is today a European school.

Ferdinand de Meeûs's descendants divided up the estate. In 1929, American businessman and ambassador William Hallam Tuck purchased part of it. Tuck was involved in the American aid for the reconstruction of Belgium after the First World War that even included Leuven University.

In 1930, William Tuck had a so-called “gentilhommière”, a manor house or country house, built on the estate. American architect William Delano drew up the plans. This “third castle” of Argenteuil is also known as “Bellevue Castle” or “Tuck Castle”. It is where Leopold III, King of Belgians, and Princess Lilian later went to live. And where the Queen Elisabeth Music Chapel will be located from next year onwards.

Back to the last century. During the Second World War, the German occupiers stabled horses at Argenteuil. After the war, in 1949, William Tuck sold his estate to Belgium’s state-owned rail company, the NMBS. Eventually, the castle became Belgian state property.

From then on, Argenteuil became closely linked to a turbulent period in the history of the Belgian monarchy. When King Leopold III was forced to abdicate due to his stand during the Second World War, Prince Karel became regent of Belgium until King Boudewijn succeeded to the throne in 1951.
Prince Karel was then offered the opportunity to live in Argenteuil, but he declined. In the 1950s, various VIPs stayed at the castle, also during the 1958 World Fair in Brussels.

In 1960 King Boudewijn marries Fabiola de Mora y Aragón, a Spanish aristocrat. The couple want to move into Laken Castle in Brussels. But Boudewijn's father and stepmother live there: the abdicated king, Leopold III, and his second wife Princess Lilian. They are obliged to leave Laken and according to witnesses, they take all their belongings, including all the castle’s furniture, with them to their new address: Argenteuil.

Leopold and Lilian move into Argenteuil Castle in 1961. There they receive all kinds of guests in what is sometimes referred to as ‘the second court’. Leopold III dies in 1983, and Princess Lilian continues to live there until her death in 2002.

The castle is in poor condition; some of the contents later turn up at various auctions. Leopold and Lilian's children – Prince Alexander, Princess Marie-Christine and Princess Marie-Esmeralda – want to turn Argenteuil into a museum, but in 2004 the Belgian state sells it.

In 2004, Jean-Marie Delwart becomes the new owner. He is a descendant of the Solvay family, a businessman in the chemical industry and a somewhat eccentric nature lover. He pays 7.8 million euros for Argenteuil and spends perhaps as much on restoring the castle.

In 2019, Delwart is getting on in years and wants to sell the building to a foundation or an organisation committed to nature or art. Not to private individuals. He claims he once received an offer from Russian President Vladimir Putin as well as from the Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi.

2025. Following the death of Jean-Marie Delwart, his heirs sell Argenteuil Castle to SPDG, a holding company belonging to the Périer-D'Ieteren family, known for its activities in the automotive sector. The sale price is reported to be 18 million euros.

21 November 2025: SPDG makes Argenteuil available to the Queen Elisabeth Music Chapel for a long period of at least 40 years. This will allow twice as many musicians to stay in residence. The Music Chapel is located about 700 metres from Argenteuil, in the same green surroundings.

Princess Esmeralda, daughter of Leopold and Lilian, responds with delight: ‘When we lived here, my father, King Leopold III, made the Argenteuil estate a special place to protect the nature he loved so much.’

‘Today, I am confident that the Queen Elisabeth Music Chapel will continue this legacy. Giving young talented artists the opportunity to develop in this green environment full of family memories, close to the Music Chapel that my grandmother created, touches me deeply.’

title: Brussels’ first ever traffic jam
first_lines: Those of us that live, work or visit the capital regularly will at one time or another have been stuck in traffic. But when did Brussels experience its first traffic jam? The Brussels regional news platform Bruzz investigated.
content: In 1958 Brussels played host to the World’s Fair. Expo 58 ran from 17 April to 19 October 1958 and attracted more than 42 million visitors from all over the World.

The World’s Fair took place on the Heizel Plateau in the north of the city’s Laken district. One of the most visited exhibits at the 1958 World’s Fair was the Atomium, an iconic Brussels landmark that still attracts visitors in droves almost 70 years later.
The flood of visitors to Brussels brought with it a big increase in the amount of traffic. It was then Brussels experienced its first traffic jams.
In order to accommodate the millions of visitors to the World’s Fair, many of whom came to Brussels by car, major investments were made in modernising the capital’s roads.

The inner ring road was widened, tunnels were built and wide boulevards were constructed to the Expo 58 site. The aim was to make the World’s Fair site and the rest of the city easily accessible for motorists. However, the sheer scale of the infrastructure work that was undertaken was instrumental in creating the traffic congestion issues that we are faced with today.

A television programme broadcast at the time that was entitled ‘Operatie Brussel’ (Operation Brussels) espoused hope for the future. Its theme tune was a children’s song with car horns sounding merrily along with the tune for good measure.

However, as soon as the World’s Fair opened to the public traffic on the city’s roads ground to a halt. A large number of visitors came by car and parked their vehicles at the side of the road wherever the could find space or simply refused to pay to park on one of the official Expo 58 carparks.  The city was unable to cope with the influx of vehicles.

The “temporary” measures taken to accommodate the increase in traffic that had been expected but underestimated remained visible decades after the World’s Fair had closed. The Koekelberg Viaduct, for example, was only taken down 26 years after Expo 58 in 1984, when what is now called the Annie Cordy Tunnel opened to traffic.

Parts of the Tervurenlaan that carries traffic from Sint-Pieters-Woluwe (Brussels) to Tervuren (Flemish Brabant) and a section of the A12 motorway were constructed in the late 1950s with the express aim of facilitating access to Expo 58 for those planning to visit the World’s Fair by car.

67 years later Brussels is one of the top ten cities in the world when it comes to traffic congestion. The navigation system manufacturer TomTom says that it currently takes an average of 27 minutes to drive 10km in Brussels. This is the same amount of time that it would take tp cover the same distance on an e-scooter. The average Brussels motorist spends more than 100 hours per annum stuck in traffic jams.

title: Discover Mary of Hungary at Mariemont
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The Mariemont Museum in Hainaut Province is putting Mary of Hungary, who served as governor of the Habsburg Netherlands, in the spotlight. She was the sister of Holy Roman Emperor Charles V and wielded considerable influence in the 16th century, both politically and artistically. An extraordinary woman, she hunted like a man, built innovative palaces and commissioned paintings from artists including Titian.
content: Mariemont in Hainaut Province literally stands for “Marie-mont” or “Mount Mary”. The name is no coincidence: the town is named after Mary of Hungary (1505-1558), who once had a hunting lodge built here.

The Mariemont Museum is currently staging a fascinating historical exhibition devoted to Mary of Hungary, “one of those regents who shaped our history and was also an important patron of Renaissance art”, explains Krista De Jonge, emeritus professor of architectural history at Leuven University. And yet her name is much less well known than that of her male contemporaries.

It’s the 16th century. Our regions are part of the Habsburg Empire. Charles V, Emperor Charles, is in power. His sister is Mary of Hungary. She grows up in Mechelen, under the care of her aunt Margaret of Austria. Her husband, the King of Hungary, is killed in the war against the Ottoman Empire leaving her widowed. ‘Underneath her widow's garb, she was a free woman,’ Krista De Jonge says.

Mary of Hungary is then appointed as governor of the Netherlands. She moves into the Coudenberg Palace in Brussels, the remains of which are located under the current Koningsplein. Immediately, she has a spacious gallery built for herself, ‘as a male ruler would do’.

Mary plays a crucial role in the succession to the throne of her nephew. Emperor Charles’s only son, Philip II, is a “prince who was raised in Spain and whom no one here knows”. Mary accompanies Charles and Philip on all kinds of joyful processions. Today, we would call this a promotion campaign. Mary, Charles and Philip: these three characters are central to the exhibition in Mariemont.

‘The apotheosis of these joyful arrivals took place in August 1549 in Mariemont and Binche,’ explains Krista De Jonge. Mary had meanwhile moved from Brussels and had had a palace built in Binche (Hainaut Province) and a hunting lodge in Mariemont. For eight days, she directed masquerades, banquets and balls, culminating in a mock battle involving hundreds of extras. The Habsburgs were fond of spectacle.

In the exhibition, images and sound allow you to experience what such a celebration must have looked like. Modern digital technology brings a rare watercolour painting of the Binche banquet hall to life. You can see the dancers moving, hear the music and the conversation in a soundscape. It is entirely scientifically accurate according to the principles of a new discipline called “archaeoacoustics”.

Nothing remains of the hunting lodge in Mariemont and only the foundations of the palace in Binche still exist. That is the tragedy of this story. ‘Hainaut was for centuries a battlefield. The hunting lodge and palace, built in modern Renaissance style, were constructed between 1547 and 1549. Barely three years later, there was an attack by the French, the arch-enemies of the Habsburgs,’ says Krista De Jonge.

‘The hunting lodge was pillaged, and even the trees that Mary had had brought from the Sonian Forest outside Brussels at great expense were uprooted.’ It was a very targeted action against Mary of Hungary, which also highlights the position of power she held.

According to the standards of the time, she remained in the shadows. But she was a woman of stature. ‘Like all Habsburgs, she loved hunting. She rode a horse like a man during dangerous wild boar hunts in the Sonian Forest; she conducted military inspections herself along the strongholds on the southern border; she held important meetings in her apartments.’

She was also an important patron of various artists, commissioning the Italian master Titian, who was asked to paint Habsburg portraits. In short, Mary of Hungary was ‘an extraordinary character. She was much more prominent than her predecessors or successors,’ says Krista De Jonge, although she certainly, as a woman, faced limitations.

The exhibition in Mariemont is not her life story but sketches the context in which this extraordinary woman lived. Paintings, sculptures, drawings, engravings, manuscripts, precious metalwork and archival documents from more than 40 museums and private collections set the scene. The ruined hunting lodge of Mariemont can be seen in a painting by Jan Brueghel, Mary’s portrait in a painting, after Titian. All kinds of handwritten documents can be viewed under glass.
A special object is a handkerchief from 1548 (!) on which a song for Mary is printed. The song has been recorded especially for this exhibition and can be viewed and listened to on site.

A brand-new addition to the Mariemont Museum itself is a 16th-century tapestry, which may depict the Mariemont hunting lodge. Over the past year, it has been perfectly treated and preserved by the Royal Manufactory De Wit in Mechelen.
Practical information: the trilingual exhibition
– part of the Europalia Spain Festival –Domain & Royal Museum of Mariemont. From 22 November 2025 to 10 May 2026.

title: Does the law allow companies to record calls made to their customer service helplines?
first_lines: Often when you call a company’s customer service department the call is recorded, usually “for quality control purposes”. This is perfectly legal as long as you are informed in advance that the call will be recorded. But what is meant by “quality control”? Kris Seyen is a legal expert specialised in privacy law. In an interview with the VRT’s consumer affairs programme WinWin, Mr Seyen explains what the law is regarding an individual’s privacy when they call a customer service department.
content: The VRT Radio 2 listener Paul Van Herck asked 'WinWin' whether a company may record a call made by him to their customer service department without him having given his express permission. He added that he has no idea what companies do with the recordings.

Kris Seyen is a legal expert in the field of privacy law. He advises customers on data protection. According to him, companies are perfectly within their rights to record a call. "They only have to clearly state that the call is or could be recorded and what the reason is why a recording is being or might be made. If you don’t wish to be recorded, the best option is to put the phone down and hope that you can contact the company online by, for example, a contact form”.

Paul Van Herck wonders what exactly is meant by “quality control” as this is invariably the reason given for a call being recorded. Kris Seyen explains that the calls are recorded either to be used later for training purposes or to enable supervisors to monitor members of their team.

'WinWin' asked several large companies whether they record the calls made to their customer service departments. Almost without exception they said that calls are recorded and that the recordings are saved and used (e.g. for training purposes) at a later date.

For example, the water company De Watergroep records every call that is made to its general switchboard number. The recordings are used to train (new) staff. The recordings are listened to during coaching session for customer service agents and are kept for 14 days.

The telecom company Proximus says that it keeps recordings made of calls by customers to its customer care and technical support centres for 1 month. Here too the recordings are used for coaching purposes. However, they are also used to enable staff to better follow up a customer’s request or complaint.

The Belgian rail company NMBS also keeps recordings of telephone calls made to its customer care centre for a month. In addition to training purposes, the recordings are also used if a complaint is made about NMBS’ customer service department.

But what if you have shared sensitive information such as your national registration number during a call to a customer service department? Can everyone just listen to a conversation containing your private and personal details during a training session?

Kris Seyen says that companies are obliged to keep the amount of personal data disclosed in recordings used for training purposes to a minimum. However, while it is easy to omit personal data from written documents by redacting them. This is more difficult with sound recordings.

Paul Van Herck fears that a company might use a recording of a telephone call against him. "Imagine that you have a heated discussion with a customer service agent on the phone or you have a dispute with the company. Could they use the recording against you?"

Kris Seyen reassures Paul that this would not be the case. "A company may only use the recording for the stated purpose. So, if a telephone conversation with a customer has been recorded for ‘quality control purposes, it may not be used as evidence against a customer. If, for example, I were to confess to one of my energy supplier’s customer service agents that I am tampering with my digital meter, the recording of the call could not be used as evidence to prosecute me”.

title: Christmas tree arrives on Brussels market square (VIDEO)
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: A pine from Sint-Katelijne-Waver in Antwerp Province was chosen this year to serve as the Christmas tree on Brussels’ historic market square.  The tree made its journey through the centre of Brussels on Thursday morning.
content: The lorry driver in charge faced quite an arduous task negotiating a route dotted with posts that today are such a feature of our urban landscape.  At times there was only a centimetre or too spare!
The pine stands 20 metres tall and weighs nearly seven tonnes.  It has to fit into a hole with a diameter of only 60cms.  The tree’s base needs to be shaved a little to allow it to fit perfectly.

The tree is now in place.  Only the lights are still missing, but they will be turned on within the week to the delight of the thousands of tourists who make for the Belgian and Flemish this Christmas.

title: Brussels’s Christmas tram gets passengers into the festive spirit
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The Brussels local transport company MIVB and its Christmas tram are getting passengers into the Christmas spirit. The decorated tram will be making its way around the city during the festive season, with Father Christmas occasionally joining in the fun.
content: The Christmas tram runs in Brussels from today. ‘The tram has Christmas lights and is decorated in red and green. Announcements of the next stop are being replaced by a Christmas choir,’ explains the MIVB’s Laurent Vermeersch.

‘We have been doing this for several years now and we have noticed that it elicits positive reactions. People enjoy riding the Christmas tram. It breaks the routine. Many people take the tram every day and when it is decorated, it creates a special atmosphere.’
From 1 December to 4 January, the Christmas tram will run on five MIVB lines: lines 9, 18, 19, 82 and 92. On 17 and 20 December, Father Christmas will be on board, handing out sweets.
On 11 December, a pop-up store opens in the Rogier metro station. Here you can buy original gifts and toys including model trams and buses and items made from recycled STIB materials.

title: Six months' imprisonment and a one-year driving ban: actor Matthias Schoenaerts convicted of driving without a licence
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Actor Matthias Schoenaerts (47) has been sentenced to 6 months in prison, a €4,000 fine and a one-year driving ban for driving without a valid licence. This was decided by the police court in Beringen. Schoenaerts was arrested last week in Pelt after allegedly refusing to take a breathalyser test.
content: Police stopped Matthias Schoenaerts, who was riding on his motorbike, in Pelt (Limburg) on 5 and on 21 April 2024, while driving without a valid driving licence. The actor had been banned from driving in Antwerp in September 2021 on account of drug use while driving and had to retake his compulsory 'recovery tests' and exams, but had failed to do so.

Schoenaerts has already been convicted by a police court 11 times in the past. He did not appear in Beringen today and was sentenced to six months' imprisonment in absentia. He will also receive a fine of €4,000, a one-year driving ban and will have to retake all his tests.
This does not mean that the actor will have to go to prison immediately. He can still lodge an  appeal.

Schoenaerts's conviction does not relate to the events of last week, when he was arrested in Pelt during a police check for allegedly refusing to take a breathalyser test. Again, he was not in possession of a valid driving licence and behaved in an uncooperative manner.

title: Lost Rubens ‘missing for centuries’ auctioned for 2.9 million euros (VIDEO)
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: A painting by the famous Antwerp painter Sir Pieter Paul Rubens (1577-1640) was sold at auction in Versailles (France) for €2.94 million at the weekend. The canvas, entitled 'Christ on the Cross', was only discovered a few months ago, after being missing for centuries.
content: The painting dating from 1613, which was thought to be lost, was found last September when an auctioneer completed the inventory and sale of a mansion in Paris, the French capital. A winning bid of 2.3 million euros was made, but with all costs included, the sale price rose to 2.94 million.

The discovery was an “extremely rare” event, according to auctioneer Jean-Pierre Osenat, who found the canvas. The painting depicts Christ crucified against a dark and threatening sky. According to Osenat, the canvas marks “the very beginning of Baroque painting”.

Prof Nils Büttner authenticated the work. Büttner is a specialist in German, Flemish and Dutch art of the 15th and 16th centuries and chairman of the Rubenianum, an Antwerp-based organisation located near the master's former studio, which focuses exclusively on Rubens' oeuvre.
Rubens painted Christ on the cross at least three more times, the most famous example of which is in the Alte Pinakothek in Munich, southern Germany.

The famous baroque painter often worked for the Church, but this work, measuring 105.5 by 72.5 centimetres, was probably intended for a private collector. It belonged to the 19th-century academic painter William Bouguereau and then to the owners of the mansion where it was found.

title: Air China to connect Brussels with Beijing and Chengdu
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The Chinese flag carrier Air China will start flights to Brussels Airport at the end of next March, the airport authorities have announced. The flights add an extra Chinese destination to the Belgian airport's network: Chengdu.
content: Air China will connect Brussels Airport with the Chinese capital Beijing – a route already served by Hainan Airlines – and with Chengdu, a metropolis in central China.

Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province, will be the fifth destination on the Chinese mainland in Brussels Airport's passenger network, after Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen and, for the past ten days, Chongqing. Hainan Airlines operates on these routes. Juneyao Air also flies between Brussels and Shanghai.
There are also Cathay Pacific flights between Brussels Airport and Hong Kong, the special administrative region.
Cargo flights between Brussels and Chengdu have already been operating for some time now.

title: Archaeologists find remains of stone dwelling from 12th or 13th century during excavations at Leuven town hall
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: During the restoration work at Leuven Town Hall, archaeologists found the remains of a stone house dating from the 12th or 13th century. It is the oldest stone house ever discovered in Leuven, and the city is calling it an “exceptional find”.
content: Leuven Town Hall is undergoing thorough restoration in coming years. During excavations in the courtyard garden of the town hall, the Vrijthof, archaeologists came across the remains of a stone house from the 12th or 13th century. Walls and a staircase have been uncovered.

According to the city authorities, this is the oldest stone house ever discovered in Leuven. ‘It is exceptional that these houses were made of stone, with walls one metre thick,’ says Dirk Vansina, alderman for Monuments and Immovable Heritage.

‘At this time, people mainly built wooden half-timbered houses, so these must have been the homes of wealthy Leuven residents. The houses were demolished in the 15th century to make way for the construction of the town hall.’
The archaeologists found even older traces under the building. They discovered the post holes of a wooden structure and a waste pit containing animal bones and ceramics.
The city will exceptionally open the gates of the Vrijthof on 6 December between 12 noon and 4 p.m. Archaeologists will be on hand to provide more information about the excavations.

title: Police find baby taken from Ghent hospital in Germany
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Police in Germany have found the baby that was taken from a Ghent hospital on Thursday, the East Flemish public prosecutor's office says. The parents took their baby from the hospital without permission and against medical advice.
content: The baby is less than a month old and requires urgent medical care. Nevertheless, the parents left the hospital in Ghent with the baby without permission.
The police and judicial authorities immediately launched an international search, with the assistance of the Belgian police missing persons unit.

At around 2 a.m. on Friday night, the police found the parents and their baby in Germany. The baby immediately received the necessary medical care. The German police questioned the parents, but they were then allowed to go.
Their baby will remain in a hospital in Germany for as long as medically necessary.

title: Belgian government bans China’s DeepSeek in the civil service
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Belgian federal government staff are no longer permitted to use applications of the Chinese AI DeepSeek system.
content: Federal government employees are no longer allowed to use applications of the Chinese AI system DeepSeek. All applications must be removed from staff members' work devices by 1 December, a circular recently published by the government modernisation minister Vanessa Matz (Francophone centrist Les Engagés) instructs.  The AI language model DeepSeek is considered to be the Chinese counterpart of America’s ChatGPT. However, privacy concerns are being raised in many countries.

The decision to ban the Chinese model from federal government services came after an analysis by Belgium’s Centre for Cybersecurity. ‘Following this analysis and taking into account the risks in terms of the protection of data transmitted to the DeepSeek system, it has been decided preventively to ban the Chinese system from federal government workplaces,’ Matz said earlier. ‘Banning the use of this system is a matter of vigilance. We guarantee that our government services are a safe, secure and an exemplary environment.’

The federal government includes federal government departments, autonomous government agencies, administrative public institutions, the public prosecutor's office, the defence ministry and the federal police. The ban also applies to staff mobile phones: ‘phones whose subscription or usage costs or purchase are partly or fully paid for by the government’.

title: 16-year-old cyclist seriously injured collision with bin lorry in Antwerp
first_lines: A 16-year-old girl has been run over by a refuse collection vehicle while she was riding her bicycle in the Het Eiland area of Antwerp. The girl was taken to the Cadix Hospital where she is currently receiving treatment for her injuries.
content: The accident happened just after 8:30am on Tuesday morning at the Kattendok-Oostkaai, in the Het Eiland area of Antwerp. The Antwerp Local Police Service says that the cyclist rode onto the road in between two parked cars.
Police spokesperson Kim Bastiaens told VRT News that the girls was unable to swerve out of ther path of the bin lorry as she attempted to cross the road.

The girl was taken to the nearby Cadix Hospital where her condition is described as being not life threatening. An investigation will be carried out into the precise circumstances surrounding the accident.
"We will interview the driver of the refuse collection vehicle and also interview the girl as soon as this is possible. CCTV footage will also be examined”, Kim Bastiaens told VRT News.

title: Belgian soldier dies after being seriously injured during mortar gun exercise in Lithuania
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Fabrice Debersaques, commander of the Brasschaat Artillery Battalion, yesterday paid tribute to Danfo Van der Velden (22), the young Belgian soldier who succumbed to his injuries sustained during a military exercise in Lithuania on Friday.
content: Details about the exact circumstances of the accident and its cause could not yet be provided. The investigation is still ongoing. A team of specialists has been sent to the scene.
The Belgian soldier was seriously injured during a mortar gun exercise in Lithuania and was taken to hospital in a critical condition, according to the Belgian Ministry of Defence.
The soldier had first received first aid at the scene and was then transferred to a civilian hospital.

An investigation has been launched to determine the exact circumstances of the incident. Further analysis should provide more clarity, according to Belgian defence minister Theo Francken (Flemish nationalist N-VA) and chief of defence Frederik Vansina.

Belgian units have been deployed in Lithuania for several months now as part of the NATO detachment “Forward Land Forces Lithuania”. The mission is part of the defence of NATO's eastern flank. The deployment is scheduled to run until the end of January.
Since the war in Ukraine and the increased Russian threat, NATO has increased its military presence in Eastern Europe.

title: Mons Indictment Chamber orders that French gangsters’ mother’s body be exhumed
first_lines: The Mons (Hainaut) Indictment Chamber has opened a new line of investigation into the as yet resolved case of the Brabant Killers. The Brabant Killers (a.k.a. the Nivelles Gang). The Francophone public broadcaster RTBF says that the Indictment Chamber has requested that the body of the mother of the French gangsters Xavier and Thierry Silman be exhumed in order for a DNA sample to be taken. This sample will be compared with samples already taken by detective working on the case.
content: The Federal Prosecutor’s Office has not confirmed that a request has been made for the body to be exhumed. However, the Francophone public broadcaster RTBF says that the Mons Indictment Chamber has ordered that the body of the mother of the French gangsters Xavier and Thierry Silman be exhumed to enable a DNA test to be carried out. Once taken, the DNA sample will be compared with samples already taken during the course of the investigation.

The Mons Indictment Chamber has accepted in part 3 of a total of 7 requests to examine new lines of investigation. A press statement read that "Given the current state of the investigation no further information will be given".

During an information meeting in June 2024, the Federal Prosecutor’s Office announce that after almost 40 years the Examining Magistrate had closed the investigation as useful lines of investigation remained open. However, the opportunity still remained for civil parties on the case to request that the Chamber of Indictment open new lines of investigation.

Several of the civil parties did so and in January this year the Mons Indictment Chamber order that statements given by two boys from Opwijk (Flemish Brabant) in 1985 should be reexamined. The boys had given detectives the registration numbers of two suspicious cars that they had jotted done.

In April 2025 the Chamber of Indictment order that a new line of investigation, this time into the Silman brothers, be opened. The brothers Xavier and Thierry Sliman and their gang carried out a series of violent robberies in Northern France at around the same time that the Brabant Killers carried out their series of violent robberies. A retired police office that has investigated their case says that there are several elements that indicate that the Silman brother were possibly involved with the Brabant killers. This is now being investigated.
